DOC.HEAD: Tenn Secretary of State Dies of Self-Inflicted Gunshot Wound
DOC.TEXT: Tennessee's secretary of state, whose office has been at the center of a bingo and political corruption scandal, died today, more than a week after shooting himself in the head. Gentry Crowell, 57, died at Vanderbilt University Medical Center, said hospital spokesman Wayne Hood. The one-time legislative power broker shot himself Dec. 12 in a suicide attempt on the front porch of his Lebanon home. As secretary of state, he was in charge of regulating bingo and spending by lobbyists and political campaigns, all of which were involved in a federal-state investigation that has resulted in 22 people being indicted or pleading guilty since January. Crowell testified in September and November before federal grand juries investigating bingo corruption in Tennessee. He said he was told by federal agents that he was not a target of the investigation. Last week, however, the Nashville Banner quoted unidentified sources as saying that federal investigaors were focusing on how Crowell solicited campaign money from architects, engineers and bingo operators. As a result of the probe one former Crowell aide, former chief bingo inspector W.D. ``Donnie'' Walker, has gone to federal prison for offenses incliding including extorting payoffs from bingo operators; his longtime administrative assistant and secretary, Mary Sue Wright, has been named an unindicted co-conspirator. She admitted taking thousands of dollars from a campaign fund. Controversy, much of it growing out of Crowell's passionate devotion to the Democratic Party, followed him during most of his 18 years in state government. He was once known as The Godfather on Capitol Hill because of his absolute, partisan control over legislation in the dual roles of chairman of the House Democratic Caucus and House Calendar Committee. The secretary of state's office had regulated charitable bingo since it was legalized for charity fund-raising in 1971. In 1989 the state Supreme Court ruled bingo unconstitutional.
